Award.AwardTitle: Graduate student workshop in symplectic and contact geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award provides partial support for a workshop to be held May 19-25, 2017 at Truckee, California. This workshop aims to introduce aspiring mathematicians in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry and from many institutions to vibrant areas of research, fostering collaboration, forming strong research ties between young researchers, and thus promoting future collaboration and research. The workshop is specifically designed to encourage the development of a diverse group of researchers in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry. It is a week-long intensive workshop, in which all activities occur under one roof. The lectures are delivered by the graduate student participants with the help of three mentors: Roger Casals (MIT), Laura Starkston (Stanford), and Steven Sivek (Bonn), who are emerging expert researchers in the field. This setup enhances communication skills, encourages active involvement or the participants and forging new collaborations.

The topic of the 2017 workshop is symplectic fillings of contact manifolds, a topic with both a rich history and lots of new ideas that are currently being developed. One major aspect of the modern understanding of symplectic fillings is via an ever-growing dichotomy in symplectic and contact geometry: flexibility versus rigidity. Some fillings can be flexible, in which case they are completely determined up to isomorphism by differential-topological data; otherwise, there is a hope that some count of J-holomorphic curves implies that the symplectic geometry is more nuanced than the underlying differential topology. One goal of the workshop is to form bridges between these two different perspectives. Notes from the lectures and further information will be available on the website https://kylerec.wordpress.com/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the 2017 Kylerec workshop, held May 19-25, 2017 at Truckee, California. The Kylerec workshop aims to introduce aspiring mathematicians in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry and from many institutions to vibrant areas of research, fostering collaboration, forming strong research ties between young researchers, and thus promoting future collaboration and research. The workshop was specifically designed to encourage the development of a diverse group of researchers in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry. It was a week-long intensive workshop, in which all activities occured under one roof. The lectures were delivered by the graduate student participants with the help of three mentors: Roger Casals (MIT), Laura Starkston (Stanford), and Steven Sivek (Bonn), who are emerging expert researchers in the field. This setup enhanced communication skills, encouraged active involvement of the participants and forged new collaborations.

The topic of the 2017 workshop was symplectic fillings of contact manifolds, a topic with both a rich history and lots of new ideas that are currently being developed. One major aspect of the modern understanding of symplectic fillings is via an ever-growing dichotomy in symplectic and contact geometry: flexibility versus rigidity. Some fillings can be flexible, in which case they are completely determined up to isomorphism by differential-topological data; otherwise, there is a hope that some count of J-holomorphic curves implies that the symplectic geometry is more nuanced than the underlying differential topology. The workshop contributed to forming bridges between these two different perspectives.

The Kylerec workshop has a strong focus on the development of young researchers, and a commitment to promoting diversity in the mathematical research community.  There were 27 participants in this workshop, the vast majority of them graduate students and a few postdoctoral fellows; a third of the participants were female. Unlike most other academic conferences, during the Kylerec workshop almost all participants delivered a talk. This immersive experience put early-career mathematicians at the very center of the workshop, as opposed to remaining a passive audience. Having participants learn their piece of the puzzle before the workshop greatly facilitated the audience's understanding of the material, and encouraged active participation during discussion sessions.
